title-group.article-title: An energy-based model for ballistic impact analysis of ceramic-composite armors

article-meta.aff: 1Aerospace Engineering Department, Indian Institute of Technology Bombay, Powai, Mumbai, India
2Aerospace Engineering Department, Indian Institute of Technology Bombay, Powai, Mumbai, India; R & D Establishment (Engineers), Pune, India
3Aerospace Engineering Department, Indian Institute of Technology Bombay, Powai, Mumbai, India

author-notes.corresp: NK Naik, Aerospace Engineering Department, Indian Institute of Technology Bombay, Powai, Mumbai 400076, India. Email: nknaik@aero.iitb.ac.in

abstract.p: An analytical model is presented for the ballistic impact behavior of ceramic-composite armors. The model is based on wave theory and energy balance between the kinetic energy of the projectile and the energy absorbed by different mechanisms. The armor analyzed consists of front composite cover layer, ceramic plate, rubber layer and the composite backing plate. The projectile is cylindrical. The major damage and energy-absorbing mechanisms are compression of the target directly below the projectile, compression in the surrounding region around the point of impact, formation of ring cracks and radial cracks in the ceramic leading to tensile failure, shear plugging, pulverization of the ceramic, tension in the yarns, delamination and matrix cracking in the composite, bulge formation on the back face of the composite backing plate and friction between the target and the projectile. Projectile erosion and deformation are also considered. Kinetic energy, velocity and deceleration of the projectile, distance traveled by the projectile and the contact force are presented as a function of time. Ballistic limit velocity, contact duration and damage progression are also given. Further, solution procedure is presented for the study of ballistic impact behavior of ceramic-composite armors. Analytical predictions are validated with the experimental results. Finally, performance of a typical ceramic-composite armor is presented.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Armors are designed to enhance personnel and vehicle survivability by defeating projectiles and fragments. It absorbs the kinetic energy of the projectile hitting the armor surface by different mechanisms. Traditionally, armors were made monolithic, usually of high hardness steel. Weapon designers are constantly improving the terminal effects of their projectiles. To overcome this, armors are becoming thicker and heavier. The increased weight of the armors reduces the mobility of its user. Hence, armor materials research strives to find solutions for the major problems associated with armors such as penetrability, weight and cost. Worldwide researchers have been trying different materials and their combinations for the development of improved armor systems.

Armor penetration by projectiles is influenced by variables such as material properties, projectile mass and incident impact velocity, projectile shape and size, target support condition and relative dimensions of the target and the projectile. Different deformation mechanisms contributing to penetration may act at different stages of the process. Knowledge of failure conditions is useful in designing a target with minimum areal density to defeat a projectile. To meet these design objectives, it is necessary to identify the important material properties and how they relate to the failure mechanisms during the penetration and perforation process.

Ceramics are attractive as armor materials because they are more weight-efficient than traditional monolithic armors against a variety of threats. This is primarily because of low density, high hardness, high compressive strength and high elastic modulus of ceramics. However, the low tensile strength typical of ceramics severely limits their performance, and thus standalone ceramic armors can be inferior to traditional steel armors.

By supporting the ceramic facing with a back-up plate, the performance of the armors can be dramatically increased. Introduction of rubber layer in between ceramic and back-up plate improves the multi-hit capabilities of the armors. A front composite cover layer protects from small damages and heat and also prevents crack growth in the ceramic plate.

The application of ceramic-composite multilayered armors is growing rapidly as the need for lighter and more agile combat vehicles increases. Armor performance strongly depends upon the threat conditions and the armor design and configuration. It is important to understand the energy dissipation and the damage mechanisms of such armor systems for understanding their behavior under ballistic impact.

Available experimental studies in the literature are specific to certain types of materials under certain ballistic impact conditions. Based on these experimental studies, the ballistic impact behavior of ceramic-composite armors cannot be fully understood. For complete understanding of this phenomenon, analytical studies are needed. Very few analytical studies are available in literature. The available analytical models are not complete and they do not take into account all the energy absorbing and damage mechanisms.

In the present study, an analytical model is presented for the prediction of ballistic impact behavior of ceramic-composite armors with a rubber layer in between ceramic and composite backing plate and a front composite cover layer. The formulation is presented for a cylindrical projectile. The analytical model is based on wave theory and energy balance between the kinetic energy of the projectile and the energy absorbed by different mechanisms. Energy absorbed by different mechanisms at different time intervals, velocity of the projectile, displacement and deceleration of the projectile, contact force and damage progression can be evaluated. Erosion and deformation of the projectile are also incorporated in the model. Further, using the analytical model, ballistic limit velocity can be determined.

sec.title: Summary of earlier studies
sec.p: Some of the earlier studies on ballistic impact performances of armors are presented in Florence (1969), Lee and Tupper (1954), Recht (1978), Tate (1967) and Taylor (1948). The very first significant analytical work was carried out by Tate (1967) on penetration process using hydrodynamic theory. He presented a modified form of hydrodynamic theory incorporating strength effect and presented a method for estimating the deceleration of the projectile and depth of penetration. His studies were on metal targets. The estimates were compared with experimental results and a good agreement was found.

Florence (1969) proposed an analytical model in which the projectile was idealized as a short cylindrical rod. A normal impact of the projectile on to the ceramic-metal plate was considered. It was argued that when the projectile strikes the hard ceramic facing, the tip shatters. Then the ceramic progressively breaks into a cone of fractured material, which subsequently spreads the impact load over a wider area of backing metallic plate. As the projectile penetrates the broken ceramic, the ductile back plate deforms and absorbs the kinetic energy of impact. He predicted ballistic limit velocity considering the energy balance between the projectile and the target. Recht (1978) presented the application of concept presented by Taylor (1948) to predict projectile deformation, projectile mass loss and plate deformation. Mass loss model for projectile included both erosion and deformation mechanisms. Erosion and deformation are governed by the plastic wave velocity in the projectile.

Woodward (1990) proposed a set of equations governing the main physical mechanisms taking part during the penetration process. He developed a one-dimensional model for the penetration into ceramic-faced armor using a lumped mass scheme. This model takes into account both the projectile and the ceramic erosion in a fairly simple manner. Chocron-Benloulo and Sachez-Galvez (1998) presented a one-dimensional analytical model for ceramic-metal target and checked against experimental data and numerical simulations.

Zera and Sachez-Galvez (1998) presented an analytical model to simulate ballistic impact of projectiles on ceramic-metal armors. The model is based on work presented by Tate (1967) for projectile penetration into ceramic and by Woodward (1990) for the behavior of metal backing plate. The predictions were compared with the experimental results. A good agreement was observed. Dinovitzer and Szymczak (1998) presented an analytical model for target fragmentation. It is based on an energy consumption approach. They assumed that there is no change in the projectile shape and size through out the penetration event.

Wen (2000, 2001) investigated the penetration and perforation of fiber-reinforced plastic laminates by rigid projectiles with different nose shapes. He developed analytical equations for predicting the penetration and perforation for different shapes of projectiles. The models are based on the assumption that deformations during a ballistic impact event are localized and the mean pressure from the laminate to resist the projectile consists of both quasi-static resistive pressure due to elastic-plastic deformation and dynamic resistive pressure due to velocity effects. The predictions are based on elastic limit, density of the target and geometry. Zhang et al. (2002) presented a dynamic model of ballistic impact against ceramic/hybrid composite. The model predicts the status of the projectile and backing material at different instances of the impact process. The model was based on work presented by Florence (1969) and low velocity impact. Equations were given for different phases to depict erosion, momentum and displacement of the projectile and the target.

Goncalves et al. (2004) analyzed the impact of projectiles against ceramic/metal armor using one-dimensional model. The model was based on equations presented by Tate (1967). The model predicts the loss of projectile mass and its velocity and the deflection of the back-up material. They also studied the effect of grain size on ballistic performance, which is very useful in the selection of materials for ballistic protection.

Recently, Naik and Doshi (2005, 2008), Naik and Shrirao (2004) and Naik et al. (2005, 2006) presented analytical models for the prediction of ballistic impact behavior of composites. The models are based on wave theory and energy balance between the projectile and the target.

Analytical studies on impact behavior of ceramics are presented by Rajendran (1994), Rajendran and Dandekar (1995), Rajendran and Kroupa (1989) and Holmquist et al. (2001). Modeling of micro-cracking and pulverization of ceramics is presented by Gailly and Espinosa (2002).

There are typical experimental studies on ballistic impact behavior of armors. Wilkins (1978) presented studies on metal and ceramic-metal targets. Mayseless (1987) presented studies on ceramic-metal targets. Shocky et al. (1990) carried out impact experiments on confined ceramics to study their failure phenomenon. Hetherington and Rajagopalan (1991) carried out experiments on ceramic-composite targets with different target thicknesses. For the same incident ballistic impact parameters, they measured residual velocities of the projectile as a function of target thickness. Navarro et al. (1993) carried out experimental studies on ballistic impact behavior of ceramic-composite armors. Ulven et al. (2003) presented experimental results on impact of bullets with different shapes on carbon/epoxy laminates. The experimental studies are for specific cases. Based on the experimental studies, the ballistic impact behavior cannot be generalized.

There are typical numerical studies on ballistic impact behavior of ceramic-composite armors by Fawaz et al. (2004). Gu and Li (2005) presented a computational method for predicting the penetration resistance of three-dimensional (3D) braided composites subjected to impact by conical–cylindrical projectile.

Sánchez Gálvez and Sánchez Paradela (2009) presented the utilization of analytical and numerical computation of ceramic/metal and ceramic/composite add-on armor failure process as valuable tools for armor design optimization. Krishnan et al. (2010) used the Johnson-Holmquist material model in LS-DYNA to study the impact phenomenon in ceramic material with ultra high molecular weight polyethylene (UHMWPE) backing material.

Xiao (2010) presented a coupled damage – plasticity model for energy absorption in composites. Krashanitsa (2011) presented a method for damage assessment of ceramics after an impact. Tang et al. (2011) investigated impact response of 3D woven composites. They also presented damage modes and microstructure. Mastilovic (2011) presented damage evolution in brittle materials under dynamic tensile loading.

Even though there are typical studies on ballistic impact behavior of ceramic-metal, metal and ceramic targets, it can be seen that there are very few studies on the ballistic impact performance of ceramic-composite armors. Ceramic and composite combination has clear advantages as an armor material compared with the other armor materials. For the effective use of ceramic-composite armors, damage and energy-absorbing mechanisms should be clearly understood. For such a need, analytical studies are more useful. In this study, an analytical model is presented for the ballistic impact analysis of ceramic–polymer matrix composite armors. The model is based on our earlier studies (Naik and Doshi, 2005; Naik et al., 2006).

sec.title: Damage and energy-absorbing mechanisms
sec.p:
A typical ceramic-composite armor is shown in Figure 1. The main structural components are ceramic and composite backing plate. The rubber layer in between ceramic and composite as well as the front composite cover layer also act as structural elements. Figure 1.
Cross-section of a typical ceramic-composite armor.

The major energy absorption is provided by the ceramic. In an ideal situation, the damage should not spread to the composite backing plate. This is because the composite plate should be able to provide the structural requirements and act as a load carrying element during post impact period even after damages have taken place in ceramic. The composite plate can also absorb energy. In such cases, it can be damaged. The rubber layer in between the ceramic and the composite delays the penetration process, Also it prevents merging of damages within the ceramic and the composite. The front composite cover layer prevents the ceramic from micro damages.
The major damage and energy-absorbing mechanisms are:

1) Ceramic
Compression of the target directly below the projectile (region 1)
Compression in the surrounding region (region 2)
Formation of ring cracks and radial cracks leading to tensile failure
Shear plugging
Pulverization
Heat generation

2) Composite backing plate.
Compression of the target directly below the projectile (region 1)
Compression in the surrounding region (region 2)
Tension in the yarns
Shear plugging
Delamination and matrix cracking
Bulge formation on the back face
Friction between the target and the projectile
Heat generation

3) Rubber
Compression
Shear plugging

4) Front composite cover layer
Shear plugging

5) Projectile
Erosion
Deformation

At higher incident impact velocities, erosion of the tip of the projectile would take place. As the velocity of the projectile decreases, deformation of the projectile would take place. Erosion and deformation of the projectile would absorb some energy during ballistic impact event. This would lead to reduction in velocity and kinetic energy of the projectile.

Figures 2(a) to (c) show different damage and energy absorption mechanisms in ceramic-composite armors during ballistic impact event. The figures show a cylindrical projectile. When the projectile strikes the target, the target would offer resistance for the penetration of the projectile into the target. As shown in Figure 2(a), the material directly below the projectile is called region 1. The surrounding material offering the resistance for penetration is called region 2. As the projectile strikes the target, longitudinal and shear stress waves are generated and travel along all the directions. Only that part of the target up to which these waves have reached would offer the resistance for penetration. The remaining portion of the target does not sense the applied impact load. As the time progresses, the stress wave would propagate further and larger part of the target would offer resistance. Figure 2.
(a) Different stages of penetration of a cylindrical projectile on to an armor. Figure 2.
(b) Different stages of penetration of a cylindrical projectile on to an armor. Figure 2.
(c) Different stages of penetration of a cylindrical projectile on to an armor.

As the projectile strikes the target, the material directly below the projectile would be under compression. The material in the surrounding region is also under compression along thickness direction. If the induced compressive stress exceeds the permissible limit, compressive failure of ceramic would take place. The induced compressive stress is calculated based on the deformation in ceramic and the distance up to which through the thickness longitudinal stress wave has traveled. Additionally, because of the impact force generated, shear stresses are also generated within the target around the periphery of the projectile. The resistance for the shear failure would be offered only by that part of the target up to which the shear wave has reached.

As the compression of the ceramic takes place during the ballistic impact event directly below the target, the ceramic along radial direction would be under tension. This can lead to the formation of ring cracks and radial cracks.

As the projectile strikes the ceramic, micro cracks would be formed in the ceramic. As the ballistic impact event progresses, the micro cracks could become macro cracks. During this phase additional micro cracks would be formed. In other words, the ceramic would be broken into granules and later into powder. The compressive strength of the ceramic powder is significantly higher than that of the ceramic plate. This indicates that as the penetration progresses, the compressive resistance offered by the ceramic/ceramic powder would increase. The process of formation of fine powdery particles from the ceramic plate is called pulverization (Gailly and Espinosa, 2002).

Different damage mechanisms such as compression, shear plugging, tension and pulverization would lead to energy absorption. As the energy is absorbed by the target, the kinetic energy of the projectile would decrease accordingly. This would lead to reduction in velocity of the projectile.

As the projectile strikes the target, resistance would be offered by the target for penetration of the projectile onto the target. If the resistance offered by the target is more, erosion of the projectile could take place. This process also would absorb some kinetic energy of the projectile leading to reduction in the velocity of the projectile. As the velocity decreases, erosion would stop and deformation of the projectile would take place.

As the ballistic impact event progresses, through the thickness, normal and shear stress waves would enter into rubber layer and composite backing plate. With this the composite backing plate as well as the rubber layer would also offer resistance to penetration and perforation. The energy-absorbing mechanisms in the rubber layer are compression and shear plugging. As the through-the-thickness longitudinal stress wave enters into the composite, compression would take place in region 1 as well as in region 2 of the composite. Because of the impact force, shear stresses are generated in the composite around the periphery of the projectile. The yarns under the projectile would be in tension. If the induced compressive stress, shear stress or tensile stress exceeds the permissible limit, failure of composite would take place. Delamination, matrix cracking and bulge formation on the back face of the composite leading to possible tensile failure of the yarns are the other damage and energy-absorbing mechanisms. During the later part of the ballistic impact event, the velocity of the projectile is very low. During this period, frictional energy would be absorbed by the target. All these damage and energy-absorbing mechanisms would absorb some energy leading to further decrease in the kinetic energy of the projectile. This would lead to further decrease in the velocity of the projectile.

Different stages of penetration of a cylindrical projectile on to the armor are shown in Figures 2(a) to (c). Figure 2[A] shows the initial position when the projectile just hits the armor. Possible erosion and deformation of the projectile are shown in Figure 2[B]. The distances traveled by different waves are also indicated in the figure. Penetration of the projectile is shown in Figures 2[C] to [E]. As through-the-thickness compressive wave reaches to the back face of the composite backing plate, bulging of the composite takes place (Figure 2[F]). Plug formation can be seen in Figure 2[G]. The projectile and the plug start moving further as shown in Figure 2[H]. Figure 2[I] shows the projectile and the plug just coming out of the back face of the composite backing plate.

sec.title: Ballistic limit velocity
sec.p: The primary objective of the armor is to arrest the projectile from penetration and perforation. Based on the structural and other requirements, the projectile can be arrested at different locations of the armor. One of the typical cases is when the tip of the projectile just reaches to the back face of the composite backing plate with zero velocity. The incident impact velocity that leads to the tip of the projectile reaching to the back face of the composite backing plate with zero velocity is defined as the ballistic limit velocity.

sec.title: Analytical formulation
sec.p:
The damage and energy-absorbing mechanisms presented in the earlier section are considered in the analytical model. Energy absorption by the projectile and the target are presented separately. The analysis is presented for the armor consisting of front composite cover layer, ceramic plate, rubber layer and composite backing plate and a cylindrical projectile. The formulation presented is based on the following assumptions:
Projectile impact is normal to the surface of the target.
The projectile is cylindrical with a flat end.
The projectile is made up of a single material.
The thickness of the armor is significantly less than the length and width of the armor. Hence armor edge effects are not considered.
During any time interval, the projectile motion is uniform and the velocity of the projectile remains constant.
The projectile material behavior is elastic – perfectly plastic.

sec.title: Wave velocity and distance traveled
sec.p: When the target is impacted by a projectile, stress waves are generated. Compressive wave and shear wave propagate along thickness direction. Tensile wave and shear wave propagate along in-plane radial direction. Stress wave velocities in the target materials as well as in the projectile are given by, (1)Czlm=λm1ρmdσzmdɛzm Cztm=λm1ρmdτzmdγzm Cxlm=λm1ρmdσxmdɛxmCxtm=λm1ρmdτxmdγxm whereλm=(1-νm)(1+νm)(1-2νm)
Here, superscript m refers to ceramic plate (c), composite backing plate (b), rubber layer (r), front composite cover layer (f) and projectile (p).
Considering linear behavior of the materials, simplified equations are given by, (2)Czlm=λmEmρm Cztm=λmGmρmCxlm=λmEmρm Cxtm=λmGmρm
Distances traveled by stress waves in time interval dt are given by, (3)Zlm=Czlmdt, Ztm=Cztmdt, Xlm=Cxlmdt, Xtm=Cxtmdt

sec.title: Energy balance
sec.p: At the beginning of the ballistic impact event, the entire energy is in the form of kinetic energy of the projectile. During the ballistic impact event, as the target and projectile deform/fail, energy is absorbed by different mechanisms. The energy absorbed during ith time interval is given by, (4)ΔEi=[ΔEep+ΔEdp]+[ΔEsf]+[ΔEc1c+ΔEc2c+ΔEsc+ΔErtc+ΔEθtc+ΔEplvc+ΔEhc] +[ΔEcr+ΔEsr]+[ΔEc1b+ΔEc2b+ΔEsb+ΔEtb+ΔEdlb+ΔEmcb+ΔEhb+ΔEfrb]
Energy balance after ith time interval is given by, (5)KEip=KEi-1p-ΔEi

sec.title: Erosion and deformation of the projectile
sec.p: When a projectile with an incident impact velocity v0 and kinetic energy KEP strikes on to a ceramic-composite armor, the interface of the projectile-armor starts moving with an interface velocity vs. After impact, energy is absorbed by different mechanisms by the armor as well as the projectile leading to decrease in the kinetic energy of the projectile. Velocity of the projectile also decreases. At any instant of time, it is given by v. The relative velocity at which the projectile approaches the target is given by vr=v-vs. Energy absorption by the projectile is by erosion and deformation of the projectile. When the velocity of the projectile v is more than the plastic wave velocity in the projectile (Cpp), erosion of the front end of the projectile would take place. This would lead to reduction in velocity of the projectile. When the velocity of the projectile is equal to or less than the plastic wave velocity in the projectile (Cpp), the projectile deformation would take place. The velocity of the projectile would further decrease and when it is equal to the projectile-armor interface velocity vs, the relative velocity at which the projectile approaches the target vr would reduce to zero and further deformation of the projectile would stop. Erosion and deformation mechanisms are explained in the next two sub-sections.

sec.title: Erosion of the projectile
sec.p: When the projectile velocity is greater than plastic wave velocity in the projectile (Cpp), the plastic wave cannot get away from the impact interface. Instead, a shock wave stands at some distance above the impact interface in place of plastic wave within the projectile. Pressure behind the shock wave is very high and the material is heated, disintegrated and/or melted. During this stage, the projectile may lose some mass and erosion of the projectile would take place. Until the velocity of the remaining portion of the projectile reduces to Cpp, material would erode further from the front end of the projectile (Recht, 1978). Erosion of the projectile would occur as long as v>Cpp (Tate, 1967).

When the projectile strikes the armor, the projectile–armor interface does not remain motionless. Consequently, the velocity of the interface must be taken into account. As given by Recht (1978), motion of the interface can be accounted for approximately using an impedance matching factor Kim, which is a function of the material properties of the projectile and the target.
Impedance matching factor between the projectile and the target is given by, (6)Kim=1+ρpCpp/{ρcKc/ρc}
For rigid materials, Kim = 1, otherwise Kim > 1. For softer materials, Kim would be larger.
On impact, the projectile may lose some mass and yielding of the projectile would take place.
The equation of motion for the remaining portion of the projectile is given by Recht (1978) (7)-Ypπ4dP2=mpdvr/dt
It may be noted that the mass of the projectile decreases due to erosion. The mass of the remaining portion of the projectile is given by, (8)mp=ρpπ/4dP2Le
Here, Le is the length of the projectile at any instant of time during erosion.
Change in the length of the projectile due to erosion depends upon relative velocity of the projectile and is given by, (9)dLe=-vrdt
Combining equations (7), (8) and (9), (10)ρpvrdvr=YpdLe/Le

At the beginning of erosion process, the relative velocity of the projectile is vr=v0/Kim (Recht, 1978). After erosion of the projectile, length and relative impact velocity of the projectile reduce to Leiand vr=v/Kim, respectively.
Integrating equation (10) from (Lei=L,vr=v0/Kim) to (Lei=Lei,vr=v/Kim), (11)Lei=Lexp{-[ρc/(2Yp)][(v0/Kim)2-(v/Kim)2]}
The length of the projectile after erosion is reduced from L to Lei. Loss of mass of the projectile due to erosion is given by, (12)dmep=mp(1-L/Lei)
It can be noted that the erosion of the projectile depends upon Kim. Higher the Kim, lower would be the erosion.

As the erosion of the projectile continues, the projectile–target interface velocity would be tending toward the velocity of the projectile. In the present analysis, projectile–target interface velocity is taken to be equal to the projectile velocity at the end of each time interval.
Velocity of the projectile-target interface is given by Recht (1978), (13)vs=v+(dmep/dt)/{ρp(π/4)dP2}

Due to erosion in the projectile, there is reduction in velocity and loss of mass of the projectile. This would lead to momentum loss of the projectile. Some energy would be absorbed due to this process. At the beginning of impact process, projectile is having mass and velocity of mp and v0, respectively. After erosion, mass of the projectile is reduced to (mp+dmep) and projectile velocity is reduced to v.
Thus, energy absorbed because of momentum loss of the projectile due to erosion is given by, (14)Eep=(1/2)mpv02-(1/2)(mp+dmep)v2

sec.title: Deformation of the projectile
sec.p:
When the impact velocity of the projectile is less than or equal to the plastic wave velocity in the projectile, erosion of the projectile would not take place. Instead, deformation of the front end of the projectile would take place. As a result of deformation, mushrooming of the front end of the projectile would take place and the diameter of the projectile would increase rapidly at the front end of the projectile. If the diameter exceeds 1.25 times the original diameter of the projectile, mass loss due to shearing of the material would take place as shown in Figure 3 (Recht, 1978). As the impact velocity reaches to the projectile–target interface velocity, deformation of the projectile would stop. This is because there is no relative velocity between the projectile and the target. So, deformation of the projectile would start at v=vd=Cpp and would end at v=vs (Recht, 1978). Here,vd is the velocity of the projectile at the beginning of deformation. During deformation, velocity of the projectile–armor interface would remain constant after achieving an initial value due to impedance match between the projectile and the target. Recht (1978) showed that, at the instant of impact, pressure balance takes place on either side of the interface provided that, (15)vs=vd/[1+{(ρcKc/ρc))/(ρpCpp)}] Figure 3.
Mushrooming of the front portion of the projectile and mass removal in shear during deformation.

Figure 4 shows the mechanism of deformation of the projectile after impact. The dashed outline shows the position of the projectile when deformation begins. There are two possibilities when the deformation of the projectile begins. The first possibility is when the projectile strikes the target at velocity v0≤Cpp. In this case, only deformation of the projectile takes place. The second possibility is when the projectile strikes the target at velocity v0 > Cpp. In this case, erosion of the projectile takes place first, and when the velocity of the projectile reduces to v ≤Cpp, the deformation of the projectile begins. Figure 4.
Decelerating force acting on the tip of the un-deformed portion of the projectile.

An elastic compressive wave having stress intensity equal to the yield stress Yp propagates through the projectile at velocity as given by equation (2). A plastic wave follows with a slower velocity Cpp. It produces required pressure to plastically extrude material laterally. Since plastic deformation is a constant volume process, the permanent enlarged cross-section App is given by, (16)App/A0p=1/(1-vr/Cpp)

When the elastic wave reaches to the free surface of the projectile at the other end, the entire un-deformed portion of the projectile is stressed. A stress relief wave propagates back toward the plastic wave front. When the relief wave reaches to the plastic wave front, the entire portion is unstressed. Strain hardened material behind the plastic wave ceases to deform. Hence, the position at which the two waves meet becomes a new interface and the process repeats itself, change in cross-section being less than before in accord with equation (16). Thus, the deformed projectile is represented by a set of discs of decreasing diameter and thickness (Recht, 1978; Taylor, 1948) as shown in Figure 4.

Lee and Tupper (1954) and Recht (1978) simply let the yield stress decelerate the un-deformed portion of the projectile, obtaining a smoother version of Taylor prediction (Taylor, 1948). The force decelerating un-deformed portion of the projectile is given by, (17)mdpdvdt=-Yp(π/4)dP2

The length up to which plastic wave has reached in the projectile is deformed. The remaining portion of the projectile length remains un-deformed. Length of the un-deformed portion of the projectile is calculated by deducting the distance traveled by the plastic wave in the projectile from the projectile length before deformation. It is given by, (18)Hi=Le-Cppdt
And the mass of the un-deformed portion of the projectile is given by, (19)mdp=ρp(π/4)dP2Hi
By solving equations (17), (18) and (19) for v and integrating v from vd to v, (20)v=vd+YpρpCppln(1-CppTLe)
Equation (20) gives the velocity of the projectile during deformation.
From equation (20), relative velocity of the projectile vr=v-vs is given by, (21)vr=vd+YpρpCppln(1-CppTLe)-vs

Strain along longitudinal direction due to deformation of the projectile as a function of original cross-section area of the projectile and cross-section area of the permanently enlarged portion is given by, (22)ɛdp=dLLe=1-AppA0p
The quantity App/A0p can be obtained from equation (16).
Energy absorption due to deformation of the projectile is, (23)Edp=∫(12Ypɛdp)dV where dV=Appvrdt
Using equation (21), time taken for complete deformation (when v=vs) is, (24)Td=LeCpp[1-exp{(vs-v0)ρpCppYp}]
The incremental thickness da of the deformed portion of the projectile is given by (Figure 4), (25)da=(Cpp-vr)dt
By volume equivalence, tip diameter of the deformed projectile is given by, (27)dPe=dP2{-1+12(L-H)(Ld-H)-3}

If the tip diameter of the projectile is more than 1.25 times the diameter of the projectile, the additional material corresponding to diameter more than 1.25 times the diameter of the projectile would be sheared off (Recht, 1978).

sec.title: Velocity and deceleration of the projectile
sec.p: Velocity of the projectile after ith time interval is, (28)vi=12mi-1pvi-12-ΔEi12mip
Here, ΔEi is the energy absorbed by the target and the projectile during ith time interval.
Deceleration of the projectile during ith time interval is, (29)dci=vi-1-vidt

sec.title: Distance traveled by the projectile
sec.p: Distance traveled by the projectile during ith time interval is, (30)Si=vi-1dt-12dcidt2

sec.title: Contact force
sec.p: Force at the tip of the projectile during ith time interval is, (31)Fi=mipdci+vi(dmip/dt)

sec.title: Case 1
sec.p: While projectile erosion is taking place (equation 13), vs=v+(dmep/dt)/{ρp(π/4)dP2}

sec.title: Case 2
sec.p: While projectile deformation is taking place (equation 15), vs=vd/{1+(ρcKm/ρm)/(ρpCpp)}

sec.title: Distance traveled by projectile–target interface
sec.p: Distance traveled by projectile–target interface is, (32)Ss=∫vsdt

sec.title: Calculations for the first time interval
sec.p: Impact duration is sub-divided into smaller time intervals. Energy balance between the kinetic energy of the projectile and the energy absorbed by different mechanisms is calculated for each time interval separately. Based on this, kinetic energy of the projectile, velocity, deceleration, distance traveled and contact force are calculated as a function of time.
Deceleration of the projectile for the first time interval based on force balance at the tip of the projectile as given by Tate (1967) is, (33)dc1=Yp(π/4)(dP)2/m0p

During the first time interval, as the projectile impacts on to the target, yielding of the projectile would take place. Equation (33) is used at the beginning of the first time interval. At this stage, the mass of the projectile does not change. The energy absorbed by the target and the projectile by different mechanisms is not known.
Based on equation (33), velocity of the projectile at the end of the first time interval is, (34)v1=v0-dc1dt
Distance traveled by the projectile during the first time interval is, (35)S1=v0dt-0.5dc1(dt)2
Force at the tip of the projectile in the first time interval is, (36)F1=m0pdc1
Energy absorbed during the first time interval based on the above calculations is, (37)ΔE1=12m0p(v02-v12)

Energy absorbed by different mechanisms by the projectile and the target is not considered in equation (37). Hence, equations (33) to (37) would not give exact values. The exact values can be obtained by considering energy absorbed by different mechanisms as given in equation (4).

Energy absorbed by different mechanisms during the first time interval is, (38)ΔE1=[ΔEep+ΔEdp]+[ΔEsf]+[ΔEc1c+ΔEc2c+ΔEsc+ΔErtc+ΔEθtc+ΔEplvc+ΔEhc] +[ΔEcr+ΔEsr]+[ΔEc1b+ΔEc2b+ΔEsb+ΔEtb+ΔEdlb+ΔEmb+ΔEhb+ΔEfrb]
Velocity of the projectile at the end of the first time interval is, (39)v1=12mpv02-ΔE112m1p
Deceleration of the projectile during the first time interval as given by equation (34) is, (40)dc1=v0-v1dt
Distance traveled by the projectile during the first time interval as given by equation (35) is, (41)S1=v0dt-0.5dc1(dt)2
Force at the tip of the projectile in the first time interval is, (42)F1=m1pdc1+v1dm1pdt

The exact values of velocity, deceleration, distance traveled, force at the tip of the projectile and energy absorbed by different mechanisms during the first time interval can be obtained iteratively using equations (38) to (42). This process is continued until ΔE1 converges. The converged value of ΔE1 would be the exact value of ΔE1.

For the second time interval, energy absorbed by different mechanisms is calculated based on contact force calculated during the first time interval. This procedure is followed for the subsequent time intervals.

sec.title: Strain calculations: Ceramic plate

list-item.p: Compressive strain in the ceramic plate in direct compression just below the projectile tip (region 1)

sec.p: The compressive strain is calculated as, (43)ɛzc1c=Fπ4(dPe)2Ec

When the projectile strikes the ceramic, the ceramic progressively breaks into a cone of fractured material, which subsequently spreads the impact load over a wider area. As proposed by Lee and Tupper (1954) and Florence (1969), the fractured cone radius is assumed to be equal to the projectile radius plus twice the ceramic thickness. This is an empirical relation and it results in a cone angle of θ=63deg. The cone angle θ=60deg to 65deg is also observed experimentally by Zera and Sanchez-Galvez (1998).
Based on the above consideration, the cone diameter at a section up to which the compressive wave has reached is, (44)de=2Zlctanθ+dP
Compressive strain in the ceramic plate in direct compression at the section up to which the compressive wave has reached is, (45)ɛzc3c=Fπ4(de)2Ec

The maximum compressive strain in the ceramic plate is at a section where the tip of the projectile is in contact with the ceramic plate. The minimum compressive strain in the ceramic plate is at a section up to which the compressive stress wave has reached. This is because the area of the ceramic plate resisting the compressive load is more at a section up to which the through the thickness compressive wave has reached. Quadratic variation of strain is considered from the section where the projectile tip is in contact with the ceramic plate to a section up to which the compressive stress wave has reached.
Strain variation from Z = S to Z = Zlc is taken in the following quadratic form: (46)ɛzcc=ɛzc3cS2-ɛzc1c(Zlc)2S2-(Zlc)2+ɛzc1c-ɛzc3cS2-(Zlc)2Z2 for S≤Z≤Zlc

The surrounding region (region 2) around the region of impact is also under compression.
Tensile strain in radial direction

Based on the geometry presented in Figure 5(a), radial tensile strain in the ceramic plate is calculated as, (47)ɛrtc=S2+(Xtc)2-XtcXtc2[1-xXtc+(dP/2)],(Xtc+dP/2)≥x≥dP/2 Figure 5.
Schematic arrangement showing tensile deformation behavior in x-direction: (a) in ceramic plate, (b) in composite backing plate.

Variation of tensile strain is taken to be linear from Xtc+dP/2 to dP/2.
Tensile strain in circumferential direction
Circumferential tensile strain in the ceramic plate is, (48)ɛθtc=S2+(Xtc)2-XtcXtc2[1-x-(dP/2)Xtc],(Xtc+dP/2)≥x≥dP/2

In this case also, variation of tensile strain is taken to be linear from Xtc+dP/2 to dP/2.
Shear resistance offered by ceramic plate
(49)Fsc=πdconeZtcSPc, where dcone=2Ztctanθ+dP
Check for penetration of the projectile into the ceramic plate
If ɛzcc > ɛcfc failure occurs in ceramic plate under compression
If ɛrtc,ɛθtc > ɛtfc failure occurs in ceramic plate under tension
If F > Fsc failure occurs in ceramic plate under shear plugging

Compressive failure of the ceramic can lead to crushing of ceramic into granules and further into powder. But penetration of the projectile into ceramic plate would take place only after failure of the ceramic either by shear plugging or tensile loading.

sec.title: Strain calculations: Composite backing plate

list-item.p: Compressive strain in the composite backing plate in z-direction

sec.p:
The compressive strain is calculated as, (50)ɛzcb=SbZlb
Tensile strain calculation in composite backing plate in x-direction (Figure 5(b))
Distance moved by the jth ply in the z-direction is, (51)Spb=Sb-jɛzcbhl

When transverse wave crosses front composite cover layer, ceramic plate and rubber layer, it starts traveling in the composite backing plate. At any instant, distance traveled by the transverse wave in composite backing plate in x-direction at the top layer (j = 0) is given by Xtb. The total number of layers that are sensing that the impact has taken place is nlsc. At the top layer of the composite backing plate, length of the fibers that are under tension is the maximum and is given by Xtb. At the last layer (j = nlsc), the fibers are not under tension.
Length of fibers in the jth ply under tension in the composite backing plate is, (52)Xptb=Xtb(nlsc-j)nlsc

Tensile strain in the composite backing plate in x-direction is, (53)ɛxtb=(Spb)2+(Xptb)2-XptbXptb+dPe/2
Shear resistance offered by the composite backing plate

Shear resistance is given by, (54)Fsb=πdPehbSPb
Check for the penetration of the projectile into the composite backing plate
If ɛzcb > ɛcfb failure occurs in composite backing plate under compression
If ɛxtb > ɛtfb failure occurs in composite backing plate under tension
If F > Fsb failure occurs in composite backing plate under shear plugging

Compressive failure of the composite backing plate can lead to crushing of the composite. But penetration of the projectile into composite backing plate would take place only after failure of the composite backing plate either by shear plugging or tensile loading.

sec.title: Energy absorption in armor by different mechanisms
Energy absorption in front composite cover layer

list-item.p: Energy absorbed in front composite cover layer by shear plugging is,

sec.title: Energy absorption in ceramic plate

list-item.p: Energy absorbed in compression of ceramic plate in region 1 is,

sec.p: Here, Acic is the cross-section area of the cone in the ceramic.

The compressive strength of fractured ceramic is taken using the empirical relation given by Holmquist et al. (2001).
Energy absorbed in compression of ceramic plate in region 2 is,
(57)Ec2c=∫0t12{Rccɛcfc}{ɛzc1c2}2π4{(dP+2Xtc)2-(dP)2}Czlcdt

The compressive strain in region 2 at z=dP would be equal to the compressive strain in region 1 whereas at a distance up to which the in-plane radial tensile wave has reached, it would be equal to zero. The energy absorbed is calculated based on average strain.
Energy absorbed in tension

As the projectile impacts the target, radial longitudinal tensile waves would be traveling in the ceramic. This can lead to straining of the ceramic along radial as well as circumferential direction, which can form radial and circumferential cracks.
Energy absorbed due to radial tension in ceramic plate is,
(58)Ertc=∫0Zlc[∫02π[∫0Xtc[∫0ɛrtcσrtcɛrtcdɛ]rdr]dφ]dZlc
If ɛrtc < ɛtfc Ertc=∫0t12{Rtcɛtfc}(ɛrtc)2π4{(2Xtc+dP)2-(dP)2}Czlcdt
If ɛrtc > ɛtfc Ertc=∫0t12Rtcɛtfcπ4{(2Xtc+dP)2-(dP)2}Czlcdt

This can lead to formation of circumferential cracks.
Energy absorbed due to circumferential tension in ceramic plate is,
(59)Eθtc=∫0Zlc[∫02π[∫dpe/2Xtc[∫0ɛθtcσθtcɛθtcdɛ]rdr]dφ]dZlc
If ɛθtc < ɛtfc Eθtc=∫0t12{Rtcɛtfc}(ɛθtc)2π4{(2Xtc+dP)2-(dP)2}Czlcdt
If ɛθtc > ɛtfc Eθtc=∫0t12Rtcɛtfcπ4{(2Xtc+dP)2-(dP)2}Czlcdt

This can lead to formation of radial cracks.
Energy absorbed due to shear plugging of ceramic plate
The resistive force against the shear plugging of the ceramic plate is given by, (60)Fsc=∫0tπdconeSPcCztcdt
Distance traveled by the transverse wave in the z-direction in one time interval is given by Ztic-Zt(i-1)c.

If the shear failure is taking place in the ceramic plate, that is, the contact force at the tip is greater than Fsc, work done or energy absorbed by the ceramic plate in shear plugging in ith time interval is given by, (61)Esic=Fsc(Ztic-Zt(i-1)c)

Total energy absorption in shear plugging of the ceramic plate is given by, (62)Esc=∑Esic
Reflected stress wave magnitude at ceramic–rubber interface can be calculated using the following equation (Meyers, 1994):
(63)σRcrσIcr=ρrCzlr-ρcCzlcρrCzlr+ρcCzlc where σIcr=σzcc at Z=(hf+hc)

It may be noted that the reflected stress wave would be tensile. If the failure of ceramic has not taken place during penetration of the projectile into ceramic plate by compression or shear plugging, tensile failure can take place because of reflected stress wave. Tensile failure of the ceramic plate can take place if σRcr≥Rtc.
Transmitted stress wave magnitude at ceramic–rubber interface can be calculated using the following equation (Meyers, 1994): (64)σTcr=σIcr2ρrCrρrCr+ρcCc

Transmitted stress wave magnitude at rubber–composite interface can be calculated using the following equation (Meyers, 1994): (65)σTrb=σIrb2ρbCbρbCb+ρrCr
Pulverization of ceramic plate

When a projectile impacts on to a ceramic target, a pulverized zone is formed ahead of the projectile tip due to intense stress conditions. Pulverization of the ceramic into fine powdery form would take place. The fine powder formed would start ejecting outward from the ceramic surface through the annular area between the projectile and the ceramic formed during penetration of the projectile. The ceramic powder just below the projectile tip would be compacted. The density of this ceramic powder would be higher than the density of bulk ceramic by a factor K1. The density of the ceramic powder ejecting out would be lower than the density of bulk ceramic by a factor K2. The path available for the ejection of the ceramic powder is the gap between the sheared ceramic plate and the projectile. The ceramic powder ejected outward by certain velocity would have some kinetic energy.
From conservation of mass of the ceramic powder during compression, (66)mplvc=vπ4(dP)2ρcK1dt

A part of this mass would be moving further as a plug along with the projectile. The remaining part would be ejected out. The mass ejected out is, (67)pplvvπ4(dP)2ρcK1dt=vplvcπ4[(1.25dP)2-(dP)2]ρcK2dt
Here, pplv is percentage of mass pulverized, that is, percentage of mass ejected out.
Velocity of the pulverized ceramic coming out, (68)vplvc=vK1pplv0.5625K2

Energy absorbed by the pulverized ceramic moving out of the surface, (69)Eplvc=12mplvc(vplvc)2
Effective mass of the projectile

The projectile impacts on to the target with certain mass. This can lead to fracture of the ceramic by compression, tension or shear plugging. The part of the fractured ceramic, which is in front of the tip of the projectile, would be moving further along with the projectile. The effective mass of the projectile would be the sum of the mass of the projectile and mass of part of the fractured ceramic that is moving along with the projectile.
The fractured ceramic mass added is, (70)dmcp=π/4dP2ρcCzlcdt

The shear plugging resistance offered by the composite backing plate at any instant is given by, (77)Fsb=∫0tπdPeSPbCztbdt
Distance traveled by the transverse wave in the z-direction in one time interval is given by, (78)Ztib-Zt(i-1)b

If the shear failure is taking place in the composite backing plate, that is, the contact force at the tip is greater than Fsb, work done or energy absorbed by the composite backing plate in shear plugging in the ith time interval is given by, (79)Esib=Fsb(Ztib-Zt(i-1)b)

Total energy absorption in shear plugging of the composite backing plate is given by, (80)Esb=∑Esib
Energy absorbed in composite backing plate due to delamination is,
(81)Edb=pdπ(Xdb)2GIICAql(N0-1)

Here, N0 is total number of layers in composite backing plate.
Energy absorbed in composite backing plate due to matrix cracking is,
(82)Emcb=pmπ(Xdb)2AqlEmtN0hlVm

sec.title: Different stages during ballistic impact event
sec.p:
The ballistic impact event as described in the analytical model can be sub-divided into four stages:
Stage 1 represents up to the time interval when through-the-thickness longitudinal compressive wave has reached to the back face of the ceramic plate. At this stage, the rubber layer and composite backing plate have not experienced the impact loading and would not offer resistance to penetration of the projectile. Even though through-the-thickness shear wave has started propagating, it has not reached to the back face of the ceramic plate. Possible damage and energy-absorbing mechanisms are compression of ceramic plate along thickness direction in region 1 as well as in region 2, tensile radial and transverse cracking in ceramic, shear plugging of ceramic, compression of ceramic in radial direction, pulverization and heat generation. Shear plugging of front composite cover layer and erosion and deformation of the projectile are the other possible energy-absorbing mechanisms.
Stage 2 represents the time interval when through-the-thickness shear wave has reached to the back face of the composite backing plate. At this stage, the shear crack front has reached to the back face of the composite backing plate. The projectile tip would be well within the composite backing plate/ceramic. The shear plug formed within the composite would not have exited the back face of the composite backing plate. Possible additional damage and energy absorption mechanisms during this stage are compression of composite backing plate along thickness direction in region 1 as well as in region 2, tension in the yarns in the composite backing plate, shear plugging of composite backing plate and delamination and matrix cracking. Shear plugging and compression of rubber layer are the other possible energy-absorbing mechanisms.
Stage 3 represents the time interval when the tip of the projectile has reached to the back face of the composite backing plate. At this stage, the velocity of the projectile is practically zero, and it has not exited from the composite backing plate. But the composite and ceramic plugs have exited from the back face of the composite backing plate. The composite plug could be in pieces, whereas the ceramic plug would be in powdery form. During this stage, the kinetic energy of the projectile would be very less. Since the shear crack front has already reached to the back face of the composite backing plate during stage 2, additional energy absorbing mechanism during stage 3 would be only frictional resistance offered by the composite to the projectile.

The incident ballistic impact velocity that leads to the tip of the projectile reaching to the back face of the composite backing plate with zero velocity is defined as the ballistic limit velocity.
Stage 4 represents the exit of the projectile from the back face of the composite backing plate. If the incident ballistic impact velocity is more than the ballistic limit velocity, the projectile would be exiting the target with certain residual velocity.

sec.title: Solution procedure
sec.p:
The objective of this formulation is to determine ballistic impact behavior of ceramic-composite armors. The emphasis is on ballistic limit velocity, ballistic impact duration, depth of penetration and possible exit velocity of the projectile. The steps involved are.
Input: Geometrical and material properties of the armor and projectile, mass and velocity of the projectile (Tables 1 to 3).
Determine the deceleration of the projectile during the first time interval based on force balance consideration at the tip of the projectile (equation (33)).
Determine the velocity of the projectile and contact force at the tip of the projectile at the end of the first time interval (equations (34) and (([A-z]))36)).
Based on the contact force calculated, calculate energy absorbed during the first time interval (equations (38), (55) to (82)).
Based on this, recalculate the deceleration of the projectile during the first time interval (equations (39) and (([A-z]))40)).
Based on this, recalculate the contact force at the tip of the projectile at the end of the first time interval (equation (42)).
Based on this, recalculate the energy absorbed by various mechanisms during the first time interval (equations (38), (55) to (82)).
This process is continued until the contact force at the tip of the projectile at the end of the first time interval is stabilized.
The solution procedure was started with time interval of 0.05 ms for the first time interval and repeated with different time intervals up to 0.5 ms. The converged values of contact force were the same for different time intervals.
Starting with this stabilized contact force, recalculate the deceleration and velocity at the end of the first time interval (equations (40) and (([A-z]))39)). These would be input parameters at the beginning of the second time interval.
Calculate energy absorbed by different mechanisms during the second time interval based on the contact force calculated during the first time interval.
Calculate velocity and contact force at the end of the second time interval.
Similarly, calculate for the third time interval.
This process is continued until the ballistic impact event is over.

sec.title: Input data necessary for the analytical predictions of ballistic impact performance
sec.p: Ballistic impact performance of typical ceramic-composite armors is studied. Geometry of the projectile and the armor as shown in Figure 1 is presented in Table 1. The projectile is cylindrical. For the analytical studies, front composite cover layer, ceramic plate, rubber layer and composite backing plate were considered. Mechanical properties of the projectile, ceramic, rubber and composite backing plate are presented in Tables 2 and 3.

The mechanical properties presented are at high strain rate loading. Compressive stress–strain data along the thickness direction for woven fabric E-glass/epoxy composite at high strain rate loading, tensile stress–strain data along the warp direction for woven fabric E-glass/epoxy composite at high strain rate loading and details regarding load-displacement behavior for the study of frictional resistance offered by the composite backing plate during the forward movement of the projectile are taken from Naik and Doshi (2008).

sec.title: Comparison of predicted and experimental results
sec.p:
Experimental studies were carried out by Hetherington and Rajagopalan (1991) and Horsfall and Buckley (1996) on ballistic impact performance of typical ceramic-composite armors. The results are presented in Table 4. Hetherington and Rajagopalan (1991) used different combinations of thicknesses of ceramic plate and composite backing plate. They used cylindrical projectiles with conical tip. Projectile diameter was 12.7 mm and projectile mass was 46.8 g. Target thickness was varied from 9 mm to 28 mm. The nominal incident ballistic impact velocity was 886 m/s. They presented the corresponding residual velocities of the projectile. Horsfall and Buckley (1996) carried out similar studies on ceramic-composite armors. The experimentally observed ballistic limit velocity was 764 m/s. Table 4.

Analytical prediction of residual velocity and ballistic limit velocity are also presented in Table 4. All the necessary mechanical properties of the armor are not presented in the papers by Hetherington and Rajagopalan (1991) and Horsfall and Buckley (1996). Hence the predictions were carried out using the mechanical properties presented in Tables 2 and 3. Overall, there is a good match between the experimental results and the analytical predictions.

sec.title: Ballistic performance of ceramic-composite armors
sec.p: The studies are carried out with alumina 99.9% as ceramic plate and geometry of the projectile and armor as given in Table 1. The energy absorbed by different energy-absorbing mechanisms, kinetic energy of the projectile, projectile and projectile–ceramic interface velocity, contact force and distance traveled by projectile tip during ballistic impact event are evaluated as a function of time.

sec.title: Case I
sec.p:
Studies were carried out with incident ballistic impact velocity of 1096 m/s. In this case, complete perforation of the target by the projectile took place, that is, the projectile tip just reached to the back face of the composite backing plate with zero velocity. Hence, the incident ballistic impact velocity of 1096 m/s is the ballistic limit velocity. The results are presented in Figures 6(a) to 9 and Tables 5 and 6. The projectile kinetic energy decreases during the ballistic impact event. This is because the energy is absorbed by the target and the projectile by different mechanisms. Figure 6.

Compressive wave reaches to back face of armor 1556 1338 1184
Transverse wave reaches to back face of armor — 39379 8191
Peak contact force 102490 47639 42649
Projectile displacement, z (mm)
Compressive wave reaches to back face of armor 5.40 5.95 6.48
Transverse wave reaches to back face of armor — 8.27 9.31
Total 7.08 40.50 40.50
Residual velocity, vR (m/s) 0 0 219.5

The major energy-absorbing mechanisms are erosion of projectile, shear plugging of ceramic and tensile failure of composite backing plate yarns. Shear plugging of composite backing plate also absorbs some energy. Energy absorbed by the other mechanisms is very less. Percentage of energy absorbed by different mechanisms is given in Table 5.

Ballistic impact parameters such as contact duration, contact force, projectile displacement and residual velocity are given in Table 6. Total contact duration is 522.14 ms (Table 6). But projectile velocity is nearly equal to zero at 15.99 ms (Figure 6 and Table 6). This time interval indicates that the through-the-thickness transverse (shear) wave has reached to the back face of the composite backing plate. The decrease in projectile velocity is very rapid initially. This is because of higher energy absorbed by projectile erosion and shear plugging of ceramic. As the velocity of the projectile decreases below the plastic wave velocity in the projectile, further erosion of the projectile would stop and deformation of the projectile would start.

Figure 7 shows projectile velocity and projectile–ceramic interface velocity. As long as erosion of the projectile is taking place, the projectile velocity would be more than the projectile–ceramic interface velocity. But the projectile velocity would be approaching to the projectile–ceramic interface velocity during the erosion process. Point a in Figure 7 indicates the end of erosion of the projectile and beginning of projectile deformation. From Figure 7, it can be seen that projectile–ceramic interface velocity and projectile velocity are nearly the same during erosion process. During the projectile deformation process, projectile–ceramic interface velocity would remain constant. But the interface velocity is significantly lower than the projectile velocity. As the through-the-thickness compressive wave crosses the back face of the ceramic, deformation of the projectile would stop. This is indicted by point b in Figure 7. After this, the projectile and projectile–ceramic interface velocities would be the same. In other words, the projectile and the ceramic would be moving forward together. Figure 7.
Projectile velocity and projectile–ceramic interface velocity during ballistic impact event, v = 1096 m/s, mp = 51 g, dP = 12.7 mm, h = 40.5 mm, ceramic-composite armor, alumina 99.9%.

Figure 8 shows contact force variation as a function of time. Point a indicates that the through-the-thickness compressive wave has reached to the back face of the ceramic whereas point b indicates that the through-the-thickness transverse wave has reached to the back face of the ceramic. Point c indicates that the through-the-thickness transverse wave has reached to the back face of the composite backing plate. Point d indicates that the erosion of the projectile has stopped, whereas Point e indicates that the through-the-thickness transverse wave has entered the composite backing plate. Points a, b and c represent the critical time intervals where the contact force could be maximum. In this case, point b represents peak contact force. Figure 8.
Contact force during ballistic impact event, v = 1096 m/s, mp = 51 g, dP = 12.7 mm, h = 40.5 mm, ceramic-composite armor, alumina 99.9%.

Figure 9 shows distances traveled by compressive wave front, shear wave front and damage front during ballistic impact event. Figure 9.
Distance traveled by compressive wave front, shear wave front and damage front during ballistic impact event, v = 1096 m/s, mp = 51 g, dP = 12.7 mm, h = 40.5 mm, ceramic-composite armor, alumina 99.9%.

sec.title: Case II
sec.p: Studies were also carried out with incident ballistic impact velocity of 1046 m/s. This is lower than the ballistic limit velocity. In this case, the total kinetic energy of the projectile would be less than the total energy that can be absorbed by the target and the projectile. The projectile would not be exiting the armor. The results are presented in Tables 5 and 6. In this case also, the major energy-absorbing mechanisms are erosion of projectile, shear plugging of ceramic and tensile failure of composite backing plate yarns. Shear plugging of composite backing plate also absorbs some energy. Energy absorbed by the other mechanisms is very less. Percentage of energy absorbed by different mechanisms is given in Table 5. Table 6 presents details regarding contact duration, contact force and projectile displacement.

sec.title: Case III
sec.p: Studies were also carried out with incident ballistic impact velocity of 1146 m/s. This is higher than the ballistic limit velocity. In this case, the total kinetic energy of the projectile would be more than the total energy that can be absorbed by the target and the projectile. The projectile would be exiting the armor with the residual velocity of 219.5 m/s. The results are presented in Tables 5 and 6. In this case also, the major energy-absorbing mechanisms are erosion of projectile, shear plugging of ceramic and tensile failure of composite backing plate yarns. Shear plugging of composite backing plate also absorbs some energy. Energy absorbed by the other mechanisms is very less. Percentage of energy absorbed by different mechanisms is given in Table 5. Table 6 presents details regarding contact duration, contact force and projectile displacement.

Comparing case I, case II and case III, it can be seen that the energy absorbed by projectile erosion increases as the incident ballistic impact velocity is increased. The energy absorbed by shear plugging of ceramic decreases as the incident ballistic impact velocity is increased (Table 5). Further, the peak contact force decreases as the incident ballistic impact velocity is increased. The total contact duration is more at ballistic impact velocity (Table 6).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
Studies are carried out on the ballistic impact performance of a typical ceramic-composite armor. Specific observations are:
The major energy-absorbing mechanisms are erosion of projectile, shear plugging of ceramic and tension in composite backing plate yarn.
Contact duration depends upon incident ballistic impact velocity. The maximum contact duration is obtained with ballistic limit velocity.

sec.p: Partial funding was provided by R&D Establishment (Engineers), Pune, India.
